Pakistan - Improvements to Financial
            Reporting and Auditing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, as well as satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Many lessons,
            nonetheless, are drawn from this experience, some among them
            follow. Projects such as this one should be framed primarily
            as initiatives designed for the reform of expenditure
            management systems, rather than merely accounting systems
            reform. If reform measures are framed in terms of resolution
            of an accounting problem (such as non-conformity with
            international accounting standards, use of an archaic chart
            of accounts, lack of timely reporting etc.), the danger is
            that it will be focused only on the reform of the
            organization, and processes related to the accounting
            function. Thus, lack of commitment should be foreseen, and
            an active support from the Ministry of Finance (MOF)
            pursued. Moreover, the scope of the system should be also
            foreseen, namely, extending the central system to
            sub-national levels: if the central government is the
            sponsor of the project, then the project should be
            restricted to central government payments, and receipts. If
            the central government wants to extend its control to
            provincial level payments, then it should have some
            financial leverage and control over provincial finances.
            Controls would be part of any budgetary control system, be
            it central or provincial. Particular care should be taken,
            so that the agency exercising the payment control function
            does not exceed limits. Specifically, use of the central
            system for provincial payments should not result in any
            additional interference from the center. Further lessons
            address issues such as lack of adequate project management
            capacity; resistance to change; orientation and training;
            the importance of getting more emphasis on change
            management, and the human side of reforms; and, on policy changes.

Pakistan - Improvement to Financial
            Reporting and Auditing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives for the Improvement to
            Financial Reporting and Auditing Project for Pakistan
            include: (a) to improve public sector accounting and
            financial systems; (b) to provide a basis for enhancing
            public sector accountability; and (c) to support improved
            institutional capacity for economic policy-making and
            management. The components will consist of: (1) government
            accounting and financial reporting; (2) government auditing;
            (3) separation of the audit and accounts functions; (4)
            institutional development (human resource management); and
            (5) institutional development (training).
